items.title: I can define redox reactions in terms of electron transfer, reduction, and oxidation
items.what: A redox reaction involves simultaneous electron transfer where reduction is the gain of electrons and oxidation is the loss of electrons. The mnemonic OILRIG helps remember: Oxidation Is Loss, Reduction Is Gain.
items.why: This fundamental definition enables identification of all redox processes, from combustion to corrosion to electrochemical cells, forming the basis for electrochemistry.
items.example: When magnesium burns in oxygen (2Mg + O2 → 2MgO), magnesium loses electrons (oxidation) while oxygen gains electrons (reduction), with electrons transferring from Mg to O2.

subtopic.name: Reduction and Oxidation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of redox reactions, including electron transfer, oxidation numbers, and identification of oxidising and reducing agents. It explains how to use oxidation numbers to track electron movement and identify redox couples in chemical reactions.
subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can explain what a redox reaction involves at the particle level
items.what: Redox reactions involve the physical movement of electrons from one chemical species to another, where the reducing agent donates electrons and the oxidising agent accepts them, occurring simultaneously.
items.why: Understanding the electron transfer mechanism explains why reduction and oxidation must occur together and helps predict which species will react in electrochemical cells.
items.example: In the reaction Cu2+(aq) + Zn(s) → Cu(s) + Zn2+(aq), electrons physically move from zinc atoms to copper ions, with zinc donating 2 electrons per atom.

subtopic.name: Reduction and Oxidation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of redox reactions, including electron transfer, oxidation numbers, and identification of oxidising and reducing agents. It explains how to use oxidation numbers to track electron movement and identify redox couples in chemical reactions.
subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can define and identify reducing agents and oxidising agents in reactions
items.what: The oxidising agent causes oxidation by accepting electrons and is itself reduced. The reducing agent causes reduction by donating electrons and is itself oxidised. The species that undergoes reduction is the oxidising agent.
items.why: Identifying these agents determines which electrode materials to use in galvanic cells and predicts the direction of spontaneous redox reactions.
items.example: In 2Mg + O2 → 2MgO, magnesium is the reducing agent (causes reduction of oxygen, gets oxidised) and oxygen is the oxidising agent (causes oxidation of magnesium, gets reduced).

subtopic.name: Reduction and Oxidation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of redox reactions, including electron transfer, oxidation numbers, and identification of oxidising and reducing agents. It explains how to use oxidation numbers to track electron movement and identify redox couples in chemical reactions.
subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can assign oxidation numbers to elements in compounds and use them to identify redox reactions
items.what: Oxidation numbers are assigned using rules: free elements = 0, pure ions = ionic charge, hydrogen = +1 (except metal hydrides = -1), oxygen = -2 (except peroxides = -1), and sum equals overall charge. Changes in oxidation numbers identify redox reactions.
items.why: Oxidation numbers provide a systematic method to identify electron transfer in complex reactions where oxidation and reduction are not immediately obvious.
items.example: In Fe2O3 + 3CO → 2Fe + 3CO2, iron changes from +3 to 0 (reduction, gains electrons) while carbon changes from +2 to +4 (oxidation, loses electrons).

subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can use oxidation numbers to distinguish redox from non-redox reactions
items.what: If any element shows a change in oxidation number during a reaction, it is a redox reaction. If no oxidation numbers change, the reaction is not redox, such as in acid-base neutralization or precipitation reactions.
items.why: This skill prevents misidentification of reaction types and ensures correct analysis when designing galvanic cells or predicting spontaneous reactions.
items.example: HCl + NaOH → NaCl + H2O is not redox (H stays +1, Cl stays -1, Na stays +1, O stays -2), but Zn + 2HCl → ZnCl2 + H2 is redox (Zn: 0→+2, H: +1→0).

subtopic.name: Reduction and Oxidation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of redox reactions, including electron transfer, oxidation numbers, and identification of oxidising and reducing agents. It explains how to use oxidation numbers to track electron movement and identify redox couples in chemical reactions.
subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can identify conjugate redox pairs using oxidation number changes
items.what: A conjugate redox pair consists of a reducing agent and its corresponding oxidising agent formed after electron donation, or an oxidising agent and its corresponding reducing agent formed after electron acceptance. Each redox reaction has two redox couples.
items.why: Identifying redox couples is essential for writing half-equations, analyzing electrochemical cells, and understanding reversible redox processes in the electrochemical series.
items.example: In Cu2+(aq) + Zn(s) → Cu(s) + Zn2+(aq), the two redox couples are Cu2+/Cu (oxidising agent/reducing agent) and Zn/Zn2+ (reducing agent/oxidising agent).

subtopic.name: Reduction and Oxidation
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the fundamental concepts of redox reactions, including electron transfer, oxidation numbers, and identification of oxidising and reducing agents. It explains how to use oxidation numbers to track electron movement and identify redox couples in chemical reactions.
subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can use oxidation numbers to identify which species is oxidised and which is reduced
items.what: An increase in oxidation number indicates oxidation (loss of electrons, becoming more positive). A decrease in oxidation number indicates reduction (gain of electrons, becoming less positive or more negative).
items.why: This allows determination of which half-cell will be the anode and which will be the cathode in galvanic cells, essential for cell design and voltage calculations.
items.example: In Fe2+(aq) → Fe3+(aq) + e-, iron oxidation number increases from +2 to +3, so iron is oxidised. In Cu2+(aq) + 2e- → Cu(s), copper decreases from +2 to 0, so copper is reduced.

subtopic.why: Understanding redox reactions is essential for analyzing electrochemical cells, batteries, and many industrial processes. These concepts form the foundation for predicting spontaneous reactions and calculating cell potentials in galvanic cells.

items.title: I can write and balance simple half-equations using the ECS method
items.what: Simple half-equations contain only one element and are balanced using ECS: balance Elements, balance Charges by adding electrons to the more positive side, add States. Electrons appear on the right for oxidation and left for reduction.
items.why: This systematic approach ensures accurate half-equations for galvanic cell reactions, preventing errors in electron number and charge balance that would make voltage calculations incorrect.
items.example: For zinc oxidation: Zn → Zn2+ (E: balanced), Zn → Zn2+ + 2e- (C: add 2e- to right), Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e- (S: add states).

subtopic.name: Writing Redox Equations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the systematic methods for writing and balancing half-equations for oxidation and reduction reactions in both acidic and basic conditions. It includes combining half-equations to form overall redox equations and extracting half-equations from complete redox reactions.
subtopic.why: Balanced half-equations are essential for understanding galvanic cell reactions, calculating quantities of reactants and products, and predicting cell behavior under different pH conditions. These skills are fundamental to electrochemistry calculations and experimental design.

items.title: I can write and balance complex half-equations in acidic conditions using KOHES
items.what: Complex half-equations contain multiple elements and use KOHES in acidic conditions: balance Key element (not H or O), balance Oxygen with H2O, balance Hydrogen with H+, balance Electrons, add States.
items.why: Many important redox reactions in galvanic cells involve oxygen-containing species requiring this method, such as permanganate or dichromate reactions in acidic solutions.
items.example: For Cr2O72- → Cr3+: K: Cr2O72- → 2Cr3+, O: Cr2O72- → 2Cr3+ + 7H2O, H: Cr2O72- + 14H+ → 2Cr3+ + 7H2O, E: Cr2O72- + 14H+ + 6e- → 2Cr3+ + 7H2O, S: add (aq) and (l).

subtopic.name: Writing Redox Equations
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the systematic methods for writing and balancing half-equations for oxidation and reduction reactions in both acidic and basic conditions. It includes combining half-equations to form overall redox equations and extracting half-equations from complete redox reactions.
subtopic.why: Balanced half-equations are essential for understanding galvanic cell reactions, calculating quantities of reactants and products, and predicting cell behavior under different pH conditions. These skills are fundamental to electrochemistry calculations and experimental design.

items.title: I can write and balance complex half-equations in basic conditions
items.what: For basic conditions, use KOHES plus two steps: after adding H+, add equal OH- to both sides to neutralize H+, then combine H+ and OH- to form H2O and cancel water molecules appearing on both sides.
items.why: Alkaline batteries and fuel cells operate in basic conditions, requiring this method to correctly represent the reactions occurring at their electrodes.
items.example: For Cr2O72- → Cr3+ in base: follow KOHES to get Cr2O72- + 14H+ + 6e- → 2Cr3+ + 7H2O, add 14OH- to both sides, combine to get 6e- + Cr2O72- + 7H2O → 2Cr3+ + 14OH-.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the systematic methods for writing and balancing half-equations for oxidation and reduction reactions in both acidic and basic conditions. It includes combining half-equations to form overall redox equations and extracting half-equations from complete redox reactions.
subtopic.why: Balanced half-equations are essential for understanding galvanic cell reactions, calculating quantities of reactants and products, and predicting cell behavior under different pH conditions. These skills are fundamental to electrochemistry calculations and experimental design.

items.title: I can combine half-equations to write overall balanced redox equations
items.what: To combine half-equations, find the lowest common multiple of electrons, multiply each half-equation to equalize electrons, add the equations together, and cancel electrons appearing on both sides.
items.why: Overall equations are needed to calculate stoichiometric relationships, predict product amounts, and understand complete galvanic cell reactions.
items.example: Combining Ag+(aq) + e- → Ag(s) and Ni(s) → Ni2+(aq) + 2e- requires multiplying silver equation by 2, giving 2Ag+(aq) + Ni(s) → 2Ag(s) + Ni2+(aq) after canceling 2e-.

items.title: I can extract half-equations from overall redox equations by identifying redox couples
items.what: Identify redox couples by finding species with the same element on both sides showing oxidation number changes. Write each pair as a half-equation, balance using ECS or KOHES, and identify as oxidation or reduction.
items.why: This reverse process allows analysis of given redox reactions, determination of which species is oxidised or reduced, and verification of electrode reactions in electrochemical cells.
items.example: From F2(g) + 2Fe2+(aq) → 2F-(aq) + 2Fe3+(aq), extract F2/F- couple: F2 + 2e- → 2F- (reduction), and Fe2+/Fe3+ couple: Fe2+ → Fe3+ + e- (oxidation).

subtopic.why: Balanced half-equations are essential for understanding galvanic cell reactions, calculating quantities of reactants and products, and predicting cell behavior under different pH conditions. These skills are fundamental to electrochemistry calculations and experimental design.

items.title: I can identify half-equations as oxidation or reduction by electron position
items.what: If electrons appear on the left side of a half-equation, it represents reduction (electrons are reactants being gained). If electrons appear on the right side, it represents oxidation (electrons are products being lost).
items.why: Quick identification of reaction type determines which electrode is the anode and which is the cathode in galvanic cells without calculating oxidation numbers.
items.example: Cu2+(aq) + 2e- → Cu(s) is reduction (electrons on left, gain), while Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e- is oxidation (electrons on right, loss).

It includes combining half-equations to form overall redox equations and extracting half-equations from complete redox reactions.
subtopic.why: Balanced half-equations are essential for understanding galvanic cell reactions, calculating quantities of reactants and products, and predicting cell behavior under different pH conditions. These skills are fundamental to electrochemistry calculations and experimental design.

items.title: I can write balanced half-equations with correct states for all species
items.what: States must be included for all species: ions are always (aq), metals are (s), water is (l), gases are (g), and electrons have no state. States reflect standard conditions at 25°C and 100 kPa.
items.why: Correct states are required for exam answers and reflect the actual physical conditions in electrochemical cells, affecting reaction feasibility and voltage.
items.example: Correct: Ni2+(aq) + 2e- → Ni(s). Incorrect: Ni2+ + 2e- → Ni (missing states) or Ni2+(s) + 2e- → Ni(aq) (wrong states for ion and metal).

items.title: I can explain the key design features that make galvanic cells function
items.what: Galvanic cells require separated half-cells to prevent direct contact between reactants, electrodes for reactions to occur on, a salt bridge to complete the circuit and balance charges, and an external circuit for electron flow.
items.why: These design features enable conversion of chemical energy to electrical energy rather than heat, making galvanic cells useful for portable power sources like batteries.
items.example: In the Daniell cell, zinc and copper half-cells are physically separated in different beakers, connected by a salt bridge, forcing electrons to flow through external wires to power devices.

subtopic.name: Galvanic Cell Features
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines the design features of galvanic cells, including the roles of separated half-cells, electrodes, salt bridges, and electrolytes. It covers how these components work together to convert chemical energy from spontaneous redox reactions into usable electrical energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding galvanic cell design is essential for battery technology, fuel cells, and electrochemical applications. These principles explain how batteries work, why certain designs are chosen, and how to optimize cell performance for different applications.

items.title: I can identify and label the cathode, anode, and their polarities in galvanic cells
items.what: The cathode is the positive electrode where reduction occurs (Happy Red Cat mnemonic). The anode is the negative electrode where oxidation occurs. Electrons flow from anode to cathode through the external circuit.
items.why: Correct identification determines which electrode materials to use, predicts direction of electron flow, and explains why certain electrodes gain or lose mass during operation.
items.example: In a zinc-copper cell, copper is the cathode (+) where Cu2+ + 2e- → Cu occurs, and zinc is the anode (-) where Zn → Zn2+ + 2e- occurs, with electrons flowing Zn to Cu.

It covers how these components work together to convert chemical energy from spontaneous redox reactions into usable electrical energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding galvanic cell design is essential for battery technology, fuel cells, and electrochemical applications. These principles explain how batteries work, why certain designs are chosen, and how to optimize cell performance for different applications.

items.title: I can explain the role and importance of separating half-cells in galvanic cells
items.what: Separated half-cells prevent direct contact between oxidising and reducing agents, forcing electrons to travel through the external circuit rather than transferring directly, converting chemical energy to electrical energy instead of heat.
items.why: Without separation, spontaneous exothermic reactions release energy as heat (as when zinc is placed directly in copper sulfate), making the energy unusable for electrical devices.
items.example: When Zn(s) is placed directly in Cu2+(aq) solution, heat is produced. When separated in a galvanic cell, the same reaction produces 1.10 volts of electrical energy to power devices.

It covers how these components work together to convert chemical energy from spontaneous redox reactions into usable electrical energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding galvanic cell design is essential for battery technology, fuel cells, and electrochemical applications. These principles explain how batteries work, why certain designs are chosen, and how to optimize cell performance for different applications.

items.title: I can describe the function of the salt bridge and direction of ion migration
items.what: The salt bridge connects half-cells, completes the circuit for charged particle flow, and maintains electrical neutrality. Anions migrate to the anode, cations migrate to the cathode, balancing charges as reactions consume or produce ions.
items.why: Without a salt bridge, charge buildup would stop the reaction within seconds. The salt bridge allows continuous operation by maintaining charge balance in both half-cells.
items.example: In a KNO3 salt bridge, K+ ions migrate toward the cathode (where Cu2+ is consumed) and NO3- ions migrate toward the anode (where Zn2+ is produced), maintaining neutrality.

It covers how these components work together to convert chemical energy from spontaneous redox reactions into usable electrical energy.
subtopic.why: Understanding galvanic cell design is essential for battery technology, fuel cells, and electrochemical applications. These principles explain how batteries work, why certain designs are chosen, and how to optimize cell performance for different applications.

items.title: I can distinguish between reactive and inert electrodes and explain their roles
items.what: Reactive electrodes participate in redox reactions, typically metals that form part of the conjugate redox pair, and change mass during operation. Inert electrodes like platinum or graphite only provide a surface for reactions without participating.
items.why: Electrode choice affects cell design, with reactive electrodes suitable when the metal is part of the reaction, while inert electrodes are required for gas or ion-only half-cells.
items.example: Zinc and copper are reactive electrodes in the Daniell cell (Zn loses mass, Cu gains mass). Platinum is an inert electrode in H2/H+ half-cells, providing surface for H2 oxidation without reacting.

items.title: I can write half-equations for reactions occurring at each electrode
items.what: At the cathode, write the reduction half-equation showing electron gain on the left. At the anode, write the oxidation half-equation showing electron loss on the right. Balance using ECS or KOHES methods.
items.why: These equations predict products formed, calculate stoichiometry, explain mass changes at electrodes, and determine the overall cell reaction and voltage.
items.example: For Daniell cell: Cathode (reduction): Cu2+(aq) + 2e- → Cu(s), mass increases. Anode (oxidation): Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e-, mass decreases.

subtopic.why: Understanding galvanic cell design is essential for battery technology, fuel cells, and electrochemical applications. These principles explain how batteries work, why certain designs are chosen, and how to optimize cell performance for different applications.

items.title: I can write overall equations for galvanic cells by combining half-equations
items.what: Combine oxidation and reduction half-equations by equalizing electrons, adding equations, and canceling electrons and any species appearing on both sides to give the net ionic equation for the cell.
items.why: Overall equations show the complete cell reaction, enable calculation of reactant consumption and product formation, and verify that the cell operates as intended.
items.example: Daniell cell: Cu2+(aq) + 2e- → Cu(s) plus Zn(s) → Zn2+(aq) + 2e- combines to give overall: Cu2+(aq) + Zn(s) → Cu(s) + Zn2+(aq).

items.title: I can draw and fully label complete galvanic cell diagrams
items.what: A complete diagram includes both half-cells with electrodes and solutions labeled, salt bridge with electrolyte identified, voltmeter showing electron flow direction, electrode polarities marked, half-equations written, and ions from salt bridge shown migrating to correct electrodes.
items.why: Diagram skills demonstrate complete understanding of cell operation and are frequently required in assessments to show all aspects of electrochemical cell function.
items.example: For Ag+/Ag and Pb2+/Pb cell: show Pb anode (-) with Pb → Pb2+ + 2e-, Ag cathode (+) with Ag+ + e- → Ag, KNO3 bridge with K+ to cathode and NO3- to anode, electrons flowing Pb to Ag.

items.title: I can explain what standard electrode potential means and how it is measured
items.what: Standard electrode potential (E0) is the voltage a half-cell produces at standard conditions (25°C, 100 kPa, 1 M solutions) measured against the standard hydrogen electrode, which is assigned 0.00 volts as the reference point.
items.why: Standard electrode potentials allow comparison of different half-cells and prediction of cell voltages, forming the basis for all electrochemical calculations and cell design.
items.example: The Cu2+/Cu half-cell has E0 = +0.34 V, meaning it produces 0.34 volts more than the hydrogen electrode under standard conditions when connected as a complete cell.

subtopic.name: Electrochemical Series
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the electrochemical series as a tool for predicting redox reactions, identifying oxidising and reducing agent strengths, and calculating cell potentials. It includes understanding standard electrode potentials, the standard hydrogen electrode reference, and limitations of the series.
subtopic.why: The electrochemical series is the primary tool for designing galvanic cells, predicting spontaneous reactions, and calculating maximum cell voltage. It enables selection of appropriate electrode materials and prediction of cell behavior under standard conditions.

items.title: I can use the electrochemical series to compare strengths of oxidising and reducing agents
items.what: Strong oxidising agents appear at the top left of the series (high positive E0), readily accepting electrons. Strong reducing agents appear at the bottom right (large negative E0), readily donating electrons. Conjugate pairs have inverse strength relationships.
items.why: Identifying relative strengths predicts which species will undergo reduction versus oxidation when mixed, essential for cell design and reaction prediction.
items.example: F2 (E0 = +2.87 V, top left) is the strongest oxidising agent. Li(s) (E0 = -3.04 V, bottom right) is the strongest reducing agent. F- is a weak reducing agent, Li+ is a weak oxidising agent.

subtopic.name: Electrochemical Series
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the electrochemical series as a tool for predicting redox reactions, identifying oxidising and reducing agent strengths, and calculating cell potentials. It includes understanding standard electrode potentials, the standard hydrogen electrode reference, and limitations of the series.
subtopic.why: The electrochemical series is the primary tool for designing galvanic cells, predicting spontaneous reactions, and calculating maximum cell voltage. It enables selection of appropriate electrode materials and prediction of cell behavior under standard conditions.

items.title: I can predict whether a spontaneous redox reaction will occur between given species
items.what: A spontaneous reaction occurs when the oxidising agent is higher on the left side of the series than the reducing agent is on the right side. If positions are reversed or both species are on the same side, no reaction occurs.
items.why: This prediction saves experimental time and resources by determining feasibility before attempting reactions, and guides selection of reactants for galvanic cells.
items.example: Pb2+(aq) (higher left) will react with Cd(s) (lower right) spontaneously. Ni2+(aq) will not react with Pb(s) because Ni2+ is lower than Pb2+ (wrong order). Pb2+ and Cd2+ won't react (both left side).

It includes understanding standard electrode potentials, the standard hydrogen electrode reference, and limitations of the series.
subtopic.why: The electrochemical series is the primary tool for designing galvanic cells, predicting spontaneous reactions, and calculating maximum cell voltage. It enables selection of appropriate electrode materials and prediction of cell behavior under standard conditions.

items.title: I can identify which half-reactions will occur in a galvanic cell from given species
items.what: When multiple species are present, the species highest on the left undergoes reduction (cathode), and the species lowest on the right undergoes oxidation (anode). Other species present act as spectator ions.
items.why: This identifies actual electrode reactions in complex mixtures, predicts products, and determines which of several possible reactions will dominate in a galvanic cell.
items.example: In a solution with Cu2+, Zn2+, and Ni2+ ions with an Fe electrode, Cu2+ (highest left, +0.34 V) reduces at cathode while Fe(s) (lowest right, -0.44 V) oxidises at anode.

subtopic.name: Electrochemical Series
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the electrochemical series as a tool for predicting redox reactions, identifying oxidising and reducing agent strengths, and calculating cell potentials. It includes understanding standard electrode potentials, the standard hydrogen electrode reference, and limitations of the series.
subtopic.why: The electrochemical series is the primary tool for designing galvanic cells, predicting spontaneous reactions, and calculating maximum cell voltage. It enables selection of appropriate electrode materials and prediction of cell behavior under standard conditions.

items.title: I can calculate standard cell potential using the electrochemical series
items.what: Standard cell potential is calculated as E0cell = E0reduction - E0oxidation, using the value from the half-reaction higher in the series minus the value from the lower half-reaction. A positive result confirms spontaneous reaction in a galvanic cell.
items.why: Cell potential determines the maximum voltage a galvanic cell can produce, enabling comparison of battery options and verification that reactions are spontaneous.
items.example: For Ag+/Ag (+0.80 V) and Pb2+/Pb (-0.13 V) cell: E0cell = +0.80 - (-0.13) = +0.93 volts. Positive value confirms spontaneous reaction with silver as cathode.

items.title: I can write complete cell equations with calculated voltages for galvanic cells
items.what: Identify reduction and oxidation half-equations from the series, balance electrons by multiplying, combine and cancel electrons, write the overall ionic equation, and add the calculated E0cell value with units.
items.why: Complete equations with voltages provide all information needed to understand cell operation, predict performance, and compare different cell configurations.
items.example: For Al3+/Al and Co2+/Co cell: 2Al(s) → 2Al3+(aq) + 6e- (E0 = +1.66 V reversed), 3Co2+(aq) + 6e- → 3Co(s) (E0 = -0.28 V), overall: 2Al(s) + 3Co2+(aq) → 2Al3+(aq) + 3Co(s), E0 = +1.38 V.

items.title: I can explain the limitations of the electrochemical series for predicting reactions
items.what: The series applies only at standard conditions (25°C, 1 M, 100 kPa). At different conditions, different reactions may occur. It does not indicate reaction rate, and some predicted reactions may be too slow to observe. Close E0 values may show unexpected behavior.
items.why: Understanding limitations prevents incorrect predictions, explains experimental discrepancies, and indicates when alternative methods or modified conditions are needed.
items.example: The series predicts H2O2 in acid should oxidise many metals, but reactions may be too slow to observe in 20 minutes. Changing concentration from 1 M to 0.1 M may cause different ions to react.

subtopic.why: The electrochemical series is the primary tool for designing galvanic cells, predicting spontaneous reactions, and calculating maximum cell voltage. It enables selection of appropriate electrode materials and prediction of cell behavior under standard conditions.

items.title: I can predict sequential reactions when one reactant is completely consumed
items.what: When the strongest oxidising or reducing agent is depleted, the next strongest species in that half-cell will begin reacting with the species in the other half-cell. Cell voltage decreases to the new value calculated from the new half-reactions.
items.why: This explains how cell voltage drops over time during discharge and predicts the complete sequence of reactions in complex mixtures with multiple reactive species.
items.example: In a half-cell with Cu2+, Ni2+, and Zn2+ with Fe anode, Cu2+ reduces first (E0 = +0.78 V). When Cu2+ is consumed, Ni2+ reduces next (E0 = +0.19 V). Reaction stops when only Zn2+ remains (below Fe in series).

subtopic.name: Electrochemical Series
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the electrochemical series as a tool for predicting redox reactions, identifying oxidising and reducing agent strengths, and calculating cell potentials. It includes understanding standard electrode potentials, the standard hydrogen electrode reference, and limitations of the series.
